_exec_summary.SummaryText:
(a)    Evonik Jayhawk Fine Chemicals accidental release prevention and emergency response policies are in force and include; Emergency Response Plan SH-014 and Environmental Management Plan MSP-023.



(b)    Evonik Jayhawk Fine Chemicals, Inc. (Jayhawk operates a batch specialty chemical manufacturing facility near Galena, Kansas.  The industrial area within which Jayhawk property and manufacturing operations are located is known locally as the Jayhawk Plant, dating back to its creation in the 1940s. That portion of the Jayhawk Plant Site containing Jayhawk property, buildings and equipment will be referred to hereinafter as the "Facility". 

    The Facility is located on approximately 850 acres of a 2,200-acre industrial     complex. Jayhawk's Unit 1 encompasses approximately 29 acres and Unit 2     encompasses approximately 25 acres. The Facility is located approximately 3.5 miles north of the junction of Kansas Route 66 and U.S. Highway 400 at     Riverton, Kansas. 



    The regulated substances handled at Jayhawk include:

1.    Acetaldehyde  CAS # 75-07-0

2.    Ammonia (water solution) 24% CAS # 7664-41-7

3.    Chlorine CAS # 7782-50-5

4.    Hydrogen Chloride CAS # 7647-01-0

5.    Isopropyl Chloroformate CAS # 108-23-6

6.    Methyl Chloroformate CAS # 79-22-01

7.    Anhydrous Ammonia CAS # 7664-41-7

8.    Methyl Chloride CAS # 74-87-3

9.     Propylene CAS# 115-07-1

10.     Phosphorous Trichloride CAS# 7719-12-2

11.     Tetramethylsilane CAS # 75-76-3

12.     Trimethylchlorosilane CAS # 75-77-4

    

(c)    Jayhawk ensures accident prevention through the development and maintenance of process safety information, performing process hazard analyses on covered systems and a program to address any deficiencies noted during the reviews, writing and maintaining current operating procedures with operator participation, training employees with appropriate knowledge to safely perform their jobs, ensuring equipment functionality with a thorough mechanical integrity program, reviewing and documenting all ch

anges affecting covered processes and training employees to the changes prior to start-up, performing pre-startup safety reviews, completing compliance audits at least every three years, investigate incidents within 48 hours of the incident and involve employees and/or contractors, following the site written employee participation plan, utilizing the site work permit policy that includes hot work permitting, complying with the site policy for contractor safety, and through training and following the site emergency response plan intended to protect human health and the environment.



NOTE:  A summary of the off-site consequence analysis (OCA) for the worst-case and alternative release scenarios(s) is no longer required to be included in the Executive Summary. While the RMP rule originally required that the Executive Summary briefly describe the OCA for worst-case and alternative release scenario(s), EPA amended the RMP rule in 2004 to remove this requirement because of security concerns. Your Executive Summary should not describe nor include information concerning your worst case or alternative release scenarios.





Worst case scenarios were developed for each regulated chemical. The assumptions made included that the chemical was instantaneously released through catastrophic failure of the container, and if there were multiple containers of a single chemical within the same proximity, the release included the entire contents of all of the containers.

    For all worst case scenarios, the following assumptions were made:

    Wind Speed:     1.5 meters/second (3.4 miles/hour)

    Stability Class:     F

    Air Temperature:     77 degrees F (25 degrees C)



Alternative case scenarios were developed for each regulated chemical. The assumptions made included that the chemical was instantaneously released through catastrophic failure of the container.

For all alternative case scenarios, the following assumptions were made:

Wind Speed:     1.5 meters/second (3.4 miles/hour)

Stability C

lass:     F

Air Temperature:     77 degrees F (25 degrees C)



Acetaldehyde

Jayhawk's facility includes a tank that contains 108,000 pounds of acetaldehyde when full. It is used as a primary raw material in the production of one of the finished products in Unit 1. Acetaldehyde stored in the quantity indicated requires that the system comply with RMP Program Level III regulations. According to US EPA's RMP*Comp A®  (RMPComp), that quantity of acetaldehyde results in a 0.3-mile radius to the one pound per square inch (p.s.i.) overpressure endpoint. The following is the RMPComp modeling results for the worst case scenario for acetaldehyde:

Category:     Flammable Gas

Liquefied     Under pressure

Quantity Released:     130,000 pounds

Release Type:     Vapor Cloud Explosion

Estimated Distance to 1 psi overpressure:     0.4 miles

The off-site consequence analysis indicates that there are no environmental receptors within the 0.4-mile radius of the acetaldehyde tank (worst case). The demographic data indicates that there are approximately 1 residential persons located within the radius of the worst case scenario.



Anhydrous Ammonia

A worse case scenario for anhydrous ammonia is the catastrophic failure of the storage tank.  Since the tank contains 96,000 pounds when full, the scenario involves the release of 96,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia through 3-inch hole.  Anhydrous ammonia stored in the quantity indicated requires that the system comply with RMP Program Level III regulations. According to RMPComp, that quantity of anhydrous ammonia results in a 3.6-mile radius to the 0.14 mg/L toxicity endpoint.  The following is the RMPComp modeling results for the worse case scenario for anhydrous ammonia:

Category:    Toxic Gas

Liquefied     Under pressure

Release Duration:     10 minutes

Release Type:     

Storage Parameters:     Release from tank

Hole or puncture area:     6.5square inches

Release Rate:     9600 pounds per min

Mitigation Measures:     NONE

Estimated Distance to 1 psi overpressur

e:    3.6 miles

The off-site consequence analysis indicates that there are no environmental receptors within the 3.6-mile radius of the anhydrous ammonia. The demographic data indicates that there are approximately 3095 persons located within the radius of the alternative case scenario.



Aqua Ammonia 24%

Jayhawk's facility includes a tank that contains 81,000 pounds of 24% (+/-) aqua ammonia. It is used as a scrubber media for the removal of nitrogen oxides from Unit 1 production processes. Aqua ammonia stored in the quantity indicated requires that the system comply with RMP Program Level III regulations. According to RMPComp, that quantity of aqua ammonia results in a 0.8-mile radius to the 0.14 mg/L toxicity endpoint. The following is the RMPComp modeling results for the worst case scenario for aqua ammonia:

Category:    Toxic Liquid

Quantity Released:    81,000 pounds

Release Duration:    10 min

Release Rate:    1,660 pounds per min

Liquid Temperature:    90 F

Mitigation Measures:     NONE

Topography:    Urban surroundings (many obstacles in the immediate area)

Toxic Endpoint:    0.14 mg/L; basis: ERPG-2

Estimated Distance to Toxic Endpoint:    0.8 miles

The off-site consequence analysis indicates that there are no environmental receptors within the 0.8-mile radius of the aqua ammonia tank (worst case). The demographic data indicates that there are approximately 14 residential persons located within the radius of the worst case scenario.



Chlorine

Jayhawk's facility includes cylinders that contain 2,000 pounds of chlorine each. A maximum of twelve (12) full cylinders will be stored on site. It is used as a primary raw material in the production of several finished products in Unit 2. Chlorine  stored in the quantity indicated requires that the system comply with RMP Program Level III regulations. According to RMPComp, that quantity of chlorine results in a 6-mile radius to the 0.0087 mg/L toxicity endpoint. The following is the ALOHA modeling results for the worst case scena

rio for chlorine:

Category:     Toxic Gas

Quantity Released:     19,360 pounds

Release Duration:     10 min

Release Rate:     6,780 pounds per min

Mitigation Measures:     NONE

Topography:     Urban surroundings (many obstacles in the immediate area)

Toxic Endpoint:     0.0087 mg/L; basis: ERPG-2

Estimated Distance to Toxic Endpoint:     6 miles

The off-site consequence analysis indicates that there are no environmental receptors within the 6-mile radius of the chlorine cylinders (worst case). The demographic data indicates that there are approximately 7308 persons located within the radius of the worst case scenario.



Hydrogen Chloride

Jayhawk's facility includes cylinders that will contain a total of 37,000 pounds of hydrogen chloride. It is used as a primary raw material in the production of products manufactured in Unit 2.  Hydrogen chloride will only be onsite in the quantity listed for approximately 90 day campaigns one to two times per year.  Hydrogen chloride stored in the quantity indicated requires that the system comply with RMP Program Level III regulations. According to RMPComp, that quantity of hydrogen chloride results in a 8.7-mile radius to the 0.030 mg/L toxicity endpoint. The following is the RMPComp modeling results for the worst case scenario for chlorine:

Category:     Toxic Gas

Quantity Released:     37,000 pounds

Release Duration:     10 min

Release Rate:     3,700 pounds per min

Mitigation Measures:     NONE

Topography:     Urban surroundings (many obstacles in the immediate area)

Toxic Endpoint:     0.030 mg/L; basis: ERPG-2

Estimated Distance to Toxic Endpoint:     8.7 miles

The off-site consequence analysis indicates that there are no environmental receptors within the 8.7-mile radius of the hydrogen chlorine cylinders (worst case). The demographic data indicates that there are approximately 15543 persons within the radius of the worst case scenario.



Isopropyl Chloroformate

Jayhawk's facility includes a refrigerated storage area that contains 55 gallon drums co

ntaining a maximum of 27,000 pounds of isopropyl chloroformate. It is used as a reactant in the production of one of the finished products in Unit 2. This chemical is normally used on-site for a single campaign to produce a specific product. It is normally not on-site more than 90 days per year. Isopropyl chloroformate stored in the quantity indicated requires that the system comply with RMP Program Level III regulations. According to RMPComp, that quantity of isopropyl chloroformate results in a 2.4-mile radius to the 0.10 mg/L toxicity endpoint. The following is the RMPComp modeling results for the worst case scenario for isopropyl chloroformate:

Category:    Toxic Liquid

Quantity Released:    27,000 pounds

Liquid Temperature:    (Refrigerated Storage Area) 40 F normal, 105 F worse case

Mitigation Measures:    Release into building with floor area of 50,000 square feet

Release Rate to Outside Air:    289 pounds per minute

Evaporation Time:    94 minutes

Topography:    Urban surroundings (many obstacles in the immediate area)

Toxic Endpoint:    0.10 mg/L; basis: EHS-LOC; LOC is based on IDLH-equivalent

level estimated from toxicity data.

Estimated Distance to Toxic Endpoint:    2.4 miles

The off-site consequence analysis indicates that there are no environmental receptors within the 2.4-mile radius of the isopropyl chloroformate storage warehouse (worst case). The demographic data indicates that there are approximately 1479 persons located within the radius of the worst case scenario.



Methyl Chloroformate

Jayhawk's facility includes 55 gal drums that contains 120,000 pounds of methyl chloroformate. Methyl chloroformate stored in the quantity indicated requires that the system comply with RMP Program Level III regulations. Methyl Chloroformate is used as a raw material in the production of one of the finished products in Unit 2.  According to RMPComp, the quantity of methyl chloroformate indicated worse case results in a 17-mile radius to the 0.0019 mg/L toxicity endpoint. The

following is the RMPComp modeling results for the worst case scenario for methyl chloroformate:

Category:     Toxic Liquid

Liquefied     Atmos

Quantity Released:     120,000 pounds

Release Duration:     868 min

Release Rate:     137 pounds per min

Mitigation Measures:     NONE

Topography:     Urban surroundings (many obstacles in the immediate area)

Toxic Endpoint:     0.0019 mg/L; basis: ERPG-2

Estimated Distance to Toxic Endpoint:     17 miles (27 kilometers)

The off-site consequence analysis indicates that there are no potential environmental receptors within the 17-mile radius of the methyl chloroformate storage (worst case). The demographic data indicates that there are approximately >21,603 persons located within the radius of the worst case scenario.



Methyl Chloride

Jayhawk's facility includes tank that contains 120,000 pounds of methyl chloride. Methyl chloride stored in the quantity indicated requires that the system comply with RMP Program Level III regulations. Methyl Chloride is used as a raw material in the production of two of the finished products in Unit 2.  According to RMPComp, the quantity of methyl chloride indicated worse case results in a 1.7-mile radius to the 0.0019 mg/L toxicity endpoint. The following is the RMPComp modeling results for the worst case scenario for methyl chloride:

Category:     Toxic Liquid

Liquefied     Atmos

Quantity Released:     120,000 pounds

Release Duration:     5 min

Release Rate:     4310 pounds per min

Mitigation Measures:     NONE

Topography:     Urban surroundings (many obstacles in the immediate area)

Toxic Endpoint:     0.0019 mg/L; basis: ERPG-2

Estimated Distance to Toxic Endpoint:     1.7 miles 

The off-site consequence analysis indicates that there are no potential environmental receptors within the 1.7-mile radius of the methyl chloride storage (worst case). The demographic data indicates that there are approximately 388 persons located within the radius of the worst case scenario.



Phosphorous Trichloride

Jayhawk facility  contain

s 42,000 pounds of PCl3 stored in bulk.  The PCl3 is used as a raw material in the production of one of the finished products in Unit 2.  According to RMPComp, the quantity of PCl3 indicated worse case results in a 2.7-mile radius to the 0.0019 mg/L toxicity endpoint. The following is the RMPComp modeling results for the worst case scenario for phosphorous trichloride:

Category:     Toxic Liquid

Liquefied     Atmos

Quantity Released:     42,000 pounds

Release Duration:     644 min

Release Rate:     93.2 pounds per min

Mitigation Measures:     Floor area

Topography:     Urban surroundings (many obstacles in the immediate area)

Toxic Endpoint:     0.0019 mg/L; basis: ERPG-2

Estimated Distance to Toxic Endpoint:     2.7 miles 

The off-site consequence analysis indicates that there are no potential environmental receptors within the 2.7-mile radius of the PCl3 storage (worst case). The demographic data indicates that there are approximately 1479 persons located within the radius of the worst case scenario.



Propylene

Jayhawk facility  contains 46,000 pounds of propylene. Propylene stored in a tank is used as a raw material in the production of one of the finished products in Unit 2.  According to RMPComp, the quantity of propylene indicated worse case results in a 0.3-mile radius to the 1 PSI endpoint. The following is the RMPComp modeling results for the worst case scenario for propylene:

Category:     Flammable Gas

Quantity Released:     46,000 pounds

Mitigation Measures:     NONE

Topography:     Urban surroundings (many obstacles in the immediate area)

1 PSI endpoint:     0.3 Miles

The off-site consequence analysis indicates that there are no potential environmental receptors within the 0.3-mile radius of the propylene storage (worst case). The demographic data indicates that there are approximately 1 persons located within the radius of the worst case scenario.



Trimethylchlorosilane

Jayhawk facility  contains 42,000 pounds of Trimehtylchlorosilane per isocontainer. Trimethylchlorosila

ne is used as a raw material for a finished material produced in Unit 2.  According to RMPComp, the quantity of trimehtylchlorosilane indicated worse case results in a 13-mile radius to the 0.0019 mg/L toxicity endpoint. The following is the RMPComp modeling results for the worst case scenario for propylene:

Category:     Toxic Liquid  Liquefied     Atmos

Quantity Released:     42,000 pounds

Release Duration:     12 min

Release Rate:     3480 pounds per min

Mitigation Measures:     Floor area

Topography:     Urban surroundings (many obstacles in the immediate area)

Toxic Endpoint:     0.0019 mg/L; basis: ERPG-2

Estimated Distance to Toxic Endpoint:     13 miles 

The off-site consequence analysis indicates that there are no potential environmental receptors within the 13-mile radius of the tetramethylsilane storage (worst case). The demographic data indicates that there are approximately 19,349 persons located within the radius of the worst case scenario.



Tetramethylsilane

Jayhawk facility  contains 42,000 pounds of tetramethylsilane. Tetramethylsilane stored in a isocontainer is one of the finished products in Unit 2.  According to RMPComp, the quantity of tertramethylsilane indicated worse case results in a 0.3-mile radius to the 1PSI endpoint. The following is the RMPComp modeling results for the worst case scenario for tetramethylsilane:

Category:     Flammable Gas

Quantity Released:     42,000 pounds

Mitigation Measures:     NONE

Topography:     Urban surroundings (many obstacles in the immediate area)

1 PSI endpoint:     0.3 Miles

The off-site consequence analysis indicates that there are no potential environmental receptors within the 0.3-mile radius of the trimethylchlorosilane storage (worst case). The demographic data indicates that there are approximately 1 persons located within the radius of the worst case scenario.







Alternate Scenarios

The catastrophic failure of the containers, or simultaneous failure of all containers for a chemical, is highly unlikely. The tanks and

cylinders have safety devices and systems to prevent or minimize the effect of any accidental release. An alternative scenario has been selected for each chemical that, although still very unlikely to occur, has a higher probability of occurrence than the worst case scenario, in accordance with U.S. EPA guidance.

For all alternative scenarios, the following assumptions were made:

Wind Speed:    3 meters/second (6.7 miles/hour)

Stability Class:    D

Air Temperature:    77 degrees F (25 degrees C)

Residential population, public receptors and environmental receptors were assessed for each chemical within the radius of its associated endpoint. In most there was residential population, no environmental receptors, and the only public receptor that appears in the available data is the Boston Mills School located one-half mile east. This school was investigated and no longer exists. Therefore, there are no public receptors within the maximum endpoint radius of the alternative case scenarios.



Acetaldehyde

A more likely scenario for acetaldehyde is the failure of the railcar unloading system. The chemical is transferred to the tank using nitrogen pressure and a closed loop system, and should a hose fail, the entire contents of the tank might escape. The alternative scenario for acetaldehyde is the failure of a 2-inch unloading line releasing all of the contents of a tank. Since the tank contains 108,000 pounds when full, the alternative scenario involves the release of 108,000 pounds of acetaldehyde through a 2-inch hose. The following is the RMPComp modeling results for the alternative scenario:

Category:    Flammable Gas

Liquefied     Under pressure

Release Duration:     19.7 minutes

Release Type:     Vapor Cloud Fire

Storage Parameters:     Release from Pipe

Hole or puncture area:     6.5 square inches

Release Rate:     5480 pounds per min

Mitigation Measures:     NONE

Estimated Distance to 1 psi overpressure:    0.1 miles

The off-site consequence analysis indicates that there are no envi

ronmental receptors within the 0.1-mile radius of the acetaldehyde tank (alternative case). The demographic data indicates that there are approximately 0 persons located within the radius of the alternative case scenario.



Anhydrous Ammonia

A more likely scenario for anhydrous ammonia is the failure of a hose during unloading. The chemical is transferred to the tank using nitrogen pressure and a closed loop system, and should a hose fail, the entire contents of the tank might escape. The alternative scenario for anhydrous ammonia is the failure of a 2-inch unloading line releasing all of the contents of a tank. Since the tank contains 96,000 pounds when full, the alternative scenario involves the release of 96,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia through a 2-inch hose. The following is the RMPComp modeling results for the alternative scenario:

Category:    Toxic Gas

Liquefied     Under pressure

Release Duration:     30 minutes

Release Type:     

Storage Parameters:     Release from hose/tank

Hole or puncture area:     3.14 square inches

Release Rate:     9600 pounds per min

Mitigation Measures:     NONE

Estimated Distance to 1 psi overpressure:    0.5 miles

The off-site consequence analysis indicates that there are no environmental receptors within the 0.5-mile radius of the anhydrous ammonia tank (alternative case). The demographic data indicates that there are approximately 1 persons located within the radius of the alternative case scenario.



Aqua Ammonia 24%

A more likely scenario for aqua ammonia is a failure during a tank trailer unloading. The chemical is transferred to the tank using air pressure, and should a hose fail, the entire contents of the tank trailer could escape. The alternative scenario for aqua ammonia is the failure of a 2-inch unloading line releasing all of the contents of a tank trailer. The volume of a single tank trailer is approximately 40,000 pounds. Therefore, the alternative scenario involves the release of 40,000 pounds of 24% aqua ammonia through a

2-inch hose. The following is the RMPComp modeling results for the alternative scenario:

Category:     Toxic Liquid

Quantity Released:     40000 pounds

Release Duration:     10 min

Release Rate:     960 pounds per minute

Liquid Temperature:     90 F

Mitigation Measures:     NONE

Topography:     Urban surroundings (many obstacles in the immediate area)

Toxic Endpoint:     0.14 mg/L; basis: ERPG-2

Estimated Distance to Toxic Endpoint:     0.3 miles

The off-site consequence analysis indicates that there are no environmental receptors within the 0.3-mile radius of the aqua ammonia tank (alternative case). The demographic data indicates that there are approximately 1 persons located within the radius of the alternative case scenario.



Chlorine

A more likely scenario for chlorine is the failures of a single cylinder during handling. Therefore, the alternative scenario involves the release of 2,000 pounds of chlorine through a 2-inch rupture in a cylinder. The following is the ALOHA modeling results for the alternative scenario:

Category:     Toxic Gas

Release Duration:     3.7 minutes

Storage Parameters:     Hole or puncture area: 3.14 square inches

Tank Pressure:     101.7 psi

Tank Temp:     70 F

Release Rate:     1746 pounds per min

Mitigation Measures:     Release into enclosed space

Topography:     Urban surroundings (many obstacles in the immediate area)

Toxic Endpoint:     0.0087 mg/L; basis: ERPG-2

Estimated Distance to Toxic Endpoint:     3 miles

The off-site consequence analysis indicates that there are no environmental receptors within the 3-mile radius of the chlorine cylinders (alternative case). The demographic data indicates that there are approximately 1479 persons located within the radius of the alternative case scenario.



Propylene

A more likely scenario for Propylene is the failures of a trailer during handling. Therefore, the alternative scenario involves the release of 14,850 pounds of Propylene through a 2-inch rupture in a container. The following is the RMPComp modeling results

for the alternative scenario:

Category:     Flammable Gas

Release Duration:     15 minutes

Storage Parameters:     Hole or puncture area: 3.14 square inches

Tank Pressure:     14.7 psi

Tank Temp:     70 F

Release Rate:     777 pounds per min

Mitigation Measures:     Release into enclosed space

Topography:     Urban surroundings (many obstacles in the immediate area)

Estimated Distance to lower flammability limit:     0.1 miles

The off-site consequence analysis indicates that there are no environmental receptors within the 0.1 mile radius of the Propylene alternative case scenario. The demographic data indicates that there are approximately 0 persons located within the radius of the alternative case scenario.





Hydrogen Chloride

A more likely scenario for hydrogen chloride is the failure of a single cylinder during handling. Therefore, the alternative scenario involves the release of 3,000 pounds of hydrogen chloride through a 2-inch rupture in a cylinder unloading connection. The following is the RMPComp modeling results for the alternative scenario:

Category:     Toxic Gas

Release Duration:     1.322 minutes

Storage Parameters:     Hole or puncture area: 3.14 square inches

Tank Pressure:     589.7 psi

Tank Temp:     70 F

Release Rate:     2270 pounds per min

Mitigation Measures:     NONE

Topography:     Urban surroundings (many obstacles in the immediate area)

Toxic Endpoint:     0.030 mg/L; basis: ERPG-2

Estimated Distance to Toxic Endpoint:     0.9 miles

The off-site consequence analysis indicates that there are no environmental receptors within the 0.9-mile radius of the hydrogen chloride cylinders (alternative case). The demographic data indicates that there are approximately 14 persons located within the radius of the alternative case scenario.



Isopropyl Chloroformate

A more likely scenario for isopropyl chloroformate is the failure of tank R-10 during process operations. In preparing to operate the batch process, approximately 5,225 pounds of isopropyl chloroformate is charged to tank

R-10. Should that reactor fail the contents could be released inside the building. Therefore, the alternative scenario involves the release of 5,225 pounds of isopropyl chloroformate through a 2-inch rupture in pipe going to the reactor. The following is the RMPComp modeling results for the alternative scenario:

Category:     Toxic Liquid

Quantity Released:     5,225 pounds

Release Duration:     1.5 minutes

Storage Parameters:     Tank under Atmospheric Pressure

Hole or puncture area:     6.5 square inches

Release Rate:     3,700 pounds per min

Liquid Temperature:     90 F

Mitigation Measures:     Release into building with floor area of 50,000 square feet

Release Rate to Outside Air:    50.9 pounds per minute

Evaporation Time:    109 min

Topography:     Urban surroundings (many obstacles in the immediate area)

Toxic Endpoint:     0.10 mg/L; basis: EHS-LOC; LOC is based on IDLH-equivalent

level estimated from toxicity data.

Estimated Distance to Toxic Endpoint:     0.1 miles

The off-site consequence analysis indicates that there are no environmental receptors within the 0.1-mile radius of the isopropyl chloroformate tank (alternative case). The demographic data indicates that there are approximately 0 persons located within the radius of the alternative case scenario. 

 

Methyl Chloroformate                                                                                          

A more likely scenario for methyl chloroformate is the failure of a 55 gal drum during process operations.  Therefore, the alternative scenario involves the release of 590 pounds of methyl chloroformate through a 1-inch rupture in the drum. The following is the RMPComp modeling results for the alternative scenario:

Category:     Toxic Liquid

Quantity Released:     590 pounds

Release Duration:     1.5 minutes

Storage Parameters:     Tank under Atmospheric Pressure

Hole or puncture area:     3.1square inches

Release Rate:     1180 pounds per min

Liquid Temperature:     90 F

Mitigation Measures:     Release into building with flo

or area of 50,000 square feet

Release Rate to Outside Air:    1.4 pounds per minute

Evaporation Time:    422 min

Topography:     Urban surroundings (many obstacles in the immediate area)

Toxic Endpoint:     0.10 mg/L; basis: EHS-LOC; LOC is based on IDLH-equivalent level estimated from toxicity data.

Estimated Distance to Toxic Endpoint:     0.2 miles

The off-site consequence analysis indicates that there are no environmental receptors within the 0.2-mile radius of Methyl Chloroformate storage area (alternative case). The demographic data indicates that there are approximately 0 persons located within the radius of the alternative case scenario.



Methyl Chloride

A more likely scenario for methyl chloride is the failure of a tank (vessel leak) during process operations.  Therefore, the alternative scenario involves the release of 21550 pounds of methyl chloride through a 1-inch rupture. The following is the RMPComp modeling results for the alternative scenario:

Category:     Toxic Liquid

Quantity Released:     21550 pounds

Release Duration:     5 minutes

Storage Parameters:     Tank under Atmospheric Pressure

Hole or puncture area:     3.1square inches

Release Rate:     4310 pounds per min

Liquid Temperature:     90 F

Mitigation Measures:     None

Release Rate to Outside Air:    1.4 pounds per minute

Evaporation Time:    422 min

Topography:     Urban surroundings (many obstacles in the immediate area)

Toxic Endpoint:     0.10 mg/L; basis: EHS-LOC; LOC is based on IDLH-equivalent

level estimated from toxicity data.

Estimated Distance to Toxic Endpoint:     0.3 miles

The off-site consequence analysis indicates that there are no environmental receptors within the 0.3-mile radius of the Methyl Chloride tank (alternative case). The demographic data indicates that there are approximately 1 persons located within the radius of the alternative case scenario.



Phosphorous Trichloride

A more likely scenario for PCl3 is the failure of a charge pipe leak during process operations.  Therefore, the alternat

ive scenario involves the release of 700 pounds of PCl3 through a 1-inch rupture. The following is the RMPComp modeling results for the alternative scenario:

Category:     Toxic Liquid

Quantity Released:     700 pounds

Release Duration:     5 minutes

Storage Parameters:     Drum under Atmospheric Pressure

Hole or puncture area:     3.1 square inches

Release Rate:     140 pounds per min

Liquid Temperature:    100 F

Mitigation Measures:     None

Release Rate to Outside Air:    1.73 pounds per minute

Evaporation Time:    404 min

Topography:     Urban surroundings (many obstacles in the immediate area)

Toxic Endpoint:     0.028 mg/L; basis: EHS-LOC; LOC is based on IDLH-equivalent

level estimated from toxicity data.

Estimated Distance to Toxic Endpoint:     0.1 miles

The off-site consequence analysis indicates that there are no environmental receptors within the 0.1-mile radius of the PCl3 drum (alternative case). The demographic data indicates that there are approximately 0 persons located within the radius of the alternative case scenario.



Trimethylchlorosilane

A more likely scenario for trimethylchlorosilane is the failure of a hose (leak) during process operations.  Therefore, the alternative scenario involves the release of 1000 pounds of trimethylchlorosilane through a 1-inch rupture. The following is the RMPComp modeling results for the alternative scenario:

Category:     Toxic Liquid

Quantity Released:     1000 pounds

Release Duration:     12 minutes

Storage Parameters:     Isocontainer under pressure

Hole or puncture area:     3.1 square inches

Release Rate: 82.8 pounds per min

Liquid Temperature:    100 F

Mitigation Measures:     None

Release Rate to Outside Air:    1.73 pounds per minute

Evaporation Time:    404 min

Topography:     Urban surroundings (many obstacles in the immediate area)

Toxic Endpoint:     0.028 mg/L; basis: EHS-LOC; LOC is based on IDLH-equivalent

level estimated from toxicity data.

Estimated Distance to Toxic Endpoint:     2.2 miles

The off-site consequence analysis indicates th

at there are no environmental receptors within the 2.2-mile radius of the PCl3 drum (alternative case). The demographic data indicates that there are approximately 442 persons located within the radius of the alternative case scenario.



Tetramethylsilane

Jayhawk facility  contains 42,000 pounds of tetramethylsilane. Tetramethylsilane stored in an isocontainer is produced as  one of the finished products in Unit 2.  According to RMPComp, the quantity of tetramethylsilane indicated alternate case results in a 0.1-mile radius to the lower flammability endpoint. The following is the RMPComp modeling results for the worst case scenario for tetramethylsilane:

Category:     Flammable Gas

Quantity Released:     42,000 pounds

Mitigation Measures:     NONE

Topography:     Urban surroundings (many obstacles in the immediate area)

Lower flammability limit:     0.1 Miles

The off-site consequence analysis indicates that there are no potential environmental receptors within the 0.1-mile radius of the trimethylchlorosilane storage (worst case). The demographic data indicates that there are approximately 0 persons located within the radius of the worst case scenario.





Jayhawk utilizes the LOPA (layer of protection analysis) for process hazard analysis of each covered process.  This detailed analysis guides the site in determining specific prevention measures to preclude accidents.



(d)    Jayhawk operates a modern facility with state of the art safety policies, practices and systems. There have been no off-site consequences involving regulated processes, or regulated chemicals, at the facility. There is no five-year accident history involving either regulated processes or chemicals that involve personnel injury, death or significant property damage.



(e)    The facility has an Emergency Response Plan intended to protect human health and the environment. There is a procedure for the notification of local emergency response agencies and the public. Training is provided to all employees on

the Emergency Response Plan and the emergency equipment available at the facility. This Emergency Response Plan is updated as often as necessary, but not less than once every three years.  Emergency response is provided by the Galena, KS Fire Department with mutual aid assistance agreements with Columbus, and Baxter Springs, KS Fire Departments. Columbus is located approximately 10 miles northwest of the facility, and Baxter Springs is located approximately 10 miles southwest of the facility. There is a Local Emergency Planning Commission (LEPC) for Cherokee County, KS. Mutual aid response times are approximately 30 minutes from the initiation of the notice. There is a Jayhawk staffed Emergency Response Team which has training in incipient stage fire response. Additional support is provided through coordination of the emergency with outside agencies through use of the plant telephone and emergency notification system.



(f)    Apart from compliance with specific guidelines, the policy of Evonik Jayhawk Fine Chemicals is also aligned to continuous development, especially in terms of plant and occupational safety, environmental protection, protecting the health of its employees, product safety, transportation safety and site security.  Specifically, EJFC operates with a policy of investigating near misses and incidents and includes findings into updates of our safety management policies and procedures.  Communication to plant personnel is routinely held to inform and train employees on improvements learned from the incident reporting management system.



Planned changes to improve safety:

Evonik Jayhawk is engaged in a new corporate safety improvement program "Safety at Evonik 2016" focusing on human behavior and safety culture.  All Evonik employees from top to bottom will be trained and required to implement in an effort to reduce incidents.

Additionally, EJFC is installing a new DCS (distributed control system)in Plant C to improve control of operating processes.
